title: 115_s1754
content: The Act may be cited as the "Training the Next Generation of Primary Care Doctors Act of 2017". The Congress enacted the program of payments to teaching health centers for graduate medical education in 2010 to address the shortage of primary care physicians, especially in rural and underserved areas. Teaching health center residents and faculty are expected to provide over one million primary care medical visits in 2017 to underserved communities. Residents who train at teaching health centers are more likely to practice primary care and stay in underserved or rural areas compared to traditional Medicare GME residents. The teaching health center program is crucial for training the next generation of primary care doctors. The teaching health center program plays a vital role in training the next generation of primary care physicians and helps address the physician shortage. It is crucial to continue funding the program under section 340H of the Public Health Service Act at a sustainable level per resident. Reauthorization of program for teaching health centers with graduate medical education programs. Reauthorization of program for teaching health centers with graduate medical education programs. Payments under section 340H of the Public Health Service Act for direct and indirect expenses to qualified teaching health centers for maintenance, expansion, and establishment of approved graduate medical residency training programs. In fiscal year 2019, up to 60 full-time equivalent residents can be supported at new approved graduate medical residency programs, increasing to 120 in fiscal year 2020. Priority is given to qualified teaching health centers serving health professional shortage areas or medically underserved communities. In fiscal year 2019, up to 60 full-time equivalent residents can be supported at new approved graduate medical residency programs, increasing to 120 in fiscal year 2020. Qualified teaching health centers in health professional shortage areas or medically underserved communities can receive payments for residents, with limitations on the number of residents per year. Funding for payments under subsection (a)(1) of section 340H of the Public Health Service Act is set at $116,500,000 for each fiscal year 2018, 2019, and 2020. This funding is available for existing programs and incentives for new programs. For payments under subsection (a)(1)(C), $10,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal year 2019 and $19,000,000 for fiscal year 2020 from the Treasury. The Secretary can use up to 5% of the amount for administrative expenses. Annual reporting requirements include the number of patients treated by residents and the number of visits by patients treated. The number of residents completing their residency training and entering primary care practice or a health care facility is reported annually. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to report on the expenses of approved graduate medical residency training programs in designated shortage areas or rural areas by March 31, 2020. This includes direct graduate expenses and indirect costs associated with teaching residents at qualified teaching health centers. The Public Health Service Act is amended to define a new approved graduate medical residency training program as one that has not received payment in a previous fiscal year. Technical corrections are made to Part D of the Act. The Public Health Service Act is amended to redefine residency training programs and make technical corrections. Section 340H is modified to replace "hospital" with "teaching health center," redesignate subpart XI as subpart XII, and redesignate section 340H as section 340I. Payments under the previous section 340H will continue for fiscal years before 2018.
